an11.18:1.1.pli: Atha kho sambahulā bhikkhū yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho te bhikkhū bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:
an11.18:1.1.eng: And then several mendicants went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

an11.18:2.1.pli: “Siyā nu kho, bhante, bhikkhuno tathārūpo samādhipaṭilābho yathā neva pathaviyaṃ pathavisaññī assa, na āpasmiṃ āposaññī assa, na tejasmiṃ tejosaññī assa, na vāyasmiṃ vāyosaññī assa, na ākāsānañcāyatane ākāsānañcāyatanasaññī assa, na viññāṇañcāyatane viññāṇañcāyatanasaññī assa, na ākiñcaññāyatane ākiñcaññāyatanasaññī assa, na nevasaññānāsaññāyatane nevasaññānāsaññāyatanasaññī assa, na idhaloke idhalokasaññī assa, na paraloke paralokasaññī assa, yampidaṃ diṭṭhaṃ sutaṃ mutaṃ viññātaṃ pattaṃ pariyesitaṃ anuvicaritaṃ manasā tatrāpi na saññī assa; saññī ca pana assā”ti?
an11.18:2.1.eng: “Could it be, sir, that a mendicant might gain a state of immersion like this? They wouldn’t perceive earth in earth, water in water, fire in fire, or air in air. And they wouldn’t perceive the dimension of infinite space in the dimension of infinite space, the dimension of infinite consciousness in the dimension of infinite consciousness, the dimension of nothingness in the dimension of nothingness, or the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception. They wouldn’t perceive this world in this world, or the other world in the other world. And they wouldn’t perceive what is seen, heard, thought, known, attained, sought, or explored by the mind. And yet they would still perceive.”

an11.18:3.1.pli: “Siyā, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno tathārūpo samādhipaṭilābho yathā neva pathaviyaṃ pathavisaññī assa …pe… yampidaṃ diṭṭhaṃ sutaṃ mutaṃ viññātaṃ pattaṃ pariyesitaṃ anuvicaritaṃ manasā tatrāpi na saññī assa; saññī ca pana assā”ti.

an11.18:4.1.pli: “Yathā kathaṃ pana, bhante, siyā bhikkhuno tathārūpo samādhipaṭilābho yathā neva pathaviyaṃ pathavisaññī assa …pe… yampidaṃ diṭṭhaṃ sutaṃ mutaṃ viññātaṃ pattaṃ pariyesitaṃ anuvicaritaṃ manasā tatrāpi na saññī assa; saññī ca pana assā”ti?

an11.18:5.2.pli: ‘etaṃ santaṃ etaṃ paṇītaṃ, yadidaṃ sabbasaṅkhārasamatho sabbūpadhipaṭinissaggo taṇhākkhayo virāgo nirodho nibbānan’ti.
an11.18:5.2.eng: ‘This is peaceful; this is sublime—that is, the stilling of all activities, the letting go of all attachments, the ending of craving, fading away, cessation, extinguishment.’

an11.18:5.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, siyā bhikkhuno tathārūpo samādhipaṭilābho yathā neva pathaviyaṃ pathavisaññī assa, na āpasmiṃ āposaññī assa, na tejasmiṃ tejosaññī assa, na vāyasmiṃ vāyosaññī assa, na ākāsānañcāyatane ākāsānañcāyatanasaññī assa, na viññāṇañcāyatane viññāṇañcāyatanasaññī assa, na ākiñcaññāyatane ākiñcaññāyatanasaññī assa, na nevasaññānāsaññāyatane nevasaññānāsaññāyatanasaññī assa, na idhaloke idhalokasaññī assa, na paraloke paralokasaññī assa, yampidaṃ diṭṭhaṃ sutaṃ mutaṃ viññātaṃ pattaṃ pariyesitaṃ anuvicaritaṃ manasā tatrāpi na saññī assa; saññī ca pana assā”ti.
an11.18:5.3.eng: That’s how a mendicant might gain a state of immersion like this. They wouldn’t perceive earth in earth, water in water, fire in fire, or air in air. And they wouldn’t perceive the dimension of infinite space in the dimension of infinite space, the dimension of infinite consciousness in the dimension of infinite consciousness, the dimension of nothingness in the dimension of nothingness, or the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception. They wouldn’t perceive this world in this world, or the other world in the other world. And they wouldn’t perceive what is seen, heard, thought, known, attained, sought, or explored by the mind. And yet they would still perceive.”

an11.19:1.1.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,

an11.19:2.1.pli: “Siyā nu kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno tathārūpo samādhipaṭilābho yathā neva pathaviyaṃ pathavisaññī assa, na āpasmiṃ āposaññī assa …pe… na ākiñcaññāyatane ākiñcaññāyatanasaññī assa, na nevasaññānāsaññāyatane nevasaññānāsaññāyatanasaññī assa, na idhaloke idhalokasaññī assa, na paraloke paralokasaññī assa, yampidaṃ diṭṭhaṃ sutaṃ mutaṃ viññātaṃ pattaṃ pariyesitaṃ anuvicaritaṃ manasā tatrāpi na saññī assa; saññī ca pana assā”ti?
an11.19:2.1.eng: “Could it be, mendicants, that a mendicant might gain a state of immersion like this? They wouldn’t perceive earth in earth, water in water, fire in fire, or air in air. And they wouldn’t perceive the dimension of infinite space in the dimension of infinite space, the dimension of infinite consciousness in the dimension of infinite consciousness, the dimension of nothingness in the dimension of nothingness, or the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception. They wouldn’t perceive this world in this world, or the other world in the other world. And they wouldn’t perceive what is seen, heard, thought, known, attained, sought, or explored by the mind. And yet they would still perceive.”

an11.19:2.2.pli: “Bhagavaṃmūlakā no, bhante, dhammā bhagavaṃnettikā bhagavaṃpaṭisaraṇā. Sādhu vata, bhante, bhagavantaṃyeva paṭibhātu etassa bhāsitassa attho. Bhagavato sutvā bhikkhū dhāressantī”ti.
an11.19:2.2.eng: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. He is our guide and our refuge. Sir, may the Buddha himself please clarify the meaning of this. The mendicants will listen and remember it.”

an11.19:3.1.pli: “Tena hi, bhikkhave, suṇātha, sādhukaṃ manasi karotha, bhāsissāmī”ti.
an11.19:3.1.eng: “Well then, mendicants, listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

an11.19:3.2.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṃ.

an11.19:4.1.pli: “Siyā, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno tathārūpo samādhipaṭilābho yathā neva pathaviyaṃ pathavisaññī assa …pe… yampidaṃ diṭṭhaṃ sutaṃ mutaṃ viññātaṃ pattaṃ pariyesitaṃ anuvicaritaṃ manasā tatrāpi na saññī assa; saññī ca pana assā”ti.
an11.19:4.1.eng: “A mendicant could gain such a state of immersion.”

an11.19:5.1.pli: “Yathā kathaṃ pana, bhante, siyā bhikkhuno tathārūpo samādhipaṭilābho yathā neva pathaviyaṃ pathavisaññī assa …pe… yampidaṃ diṭṭhaṃ sutaṃ mutaṃ viññātaṃ pattaṃ pariyesitaṃ anuvicaritaṃ manasā tatrāpi na saññī assa; saññī ca pana assā”ti?

an11.19:6.2.pli: ‘etaṃ santaṃ etaṃ paṇītaṃ, yadidaṃ sabbasaṅkhārasamatho sabbūpadhipaṭinissaggo taṇhākkhayo virāgo nirodho nibbānan’ti.
an11.19:6.2.eng: ‘This is peaceful; this is sublime—that is, the stilling of all activities, the letting go of all attachments, the ending of craving, fading away, cessation, extinguishment.’

an11.19:6.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, siyā bhikkhuno tathārūpo samādhipaṭilābho yathā neva pathaviyaṃ pathavisaññī assa …pe… yampidaṃ diṭṭhaṃ sutaṃ mutaṃ viññātaṃ pattaṃ pariyesitaṃ anuvicaritaṃ manasā tatrāpi na saññī assa; saññī ca pana assā”ti.
an11.19:6.3.eng: That’s how a mendicant might gain a state of immersion like this. They wouldn’t perceive earth in earth, water in water, fire in fire, or air in air. And they wouldn’t perceive the dimension of infinite space in the dimension of infinite space, the dimension of infinite consciousness in the dimension of infinite consciousness, the dimension of nothingness in the dimension of nothingness, or the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception. They wouldn’t perceive this world in this world, or the other world in the other world. And they wouldn’t perceive what is seen, heard, thought, known, attained, sought, or explored by the mind. And yet they would still perceive.”

an11.2:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, an ethical person, who has fulfilled ethical conduct, need not make a wish:

an11.2:1.3.pli: Dhammatā esā, bhikkhave, yaṃ sīlavato sīlasampannassa avippaṭisāro uppajjati.
an11.2:1.3.eng: It’s only natural that an ethical person has no regrets.

an11.2:2.1.eng: When you have no regrets you need not make a wish:

an11.2:2.3.pli: Dhammatā esā, bhikkhave, yaṃ avippaṭisārissa pāmojjaṃ uppajjati.
an11.2:2.3.eng: It’s only natural that joy springs up when you have no regrets.

an11.2:3.1.eng: When you feel joy you need not make a wish:

an11.2:3.3.pli: Dhammatā esā, bhikkhave, yaṃ pamuditassa pīti uppajjati.
an11.2:3.3.eng: It’s only natural that rapture arises when you’re joyful.

an11.2:4.1.eng: When your mind is full of rapture you need not make a wish:

an11.2:4.3.pli: Dhammatā esā, bhikkhave, yaṃ pītimanassa kāyo passambhati.
an11.2:4.3.eng: It’s only natural that your body becomes tranquil when your mind is full of rapture.

an11.2:5.1.eng: When your body is tranquil you need not make a wish:

an11.2:5.3.pli: Dhammatā esā, bhikkhave, yaṃ passaddhakāyo sukhaṃ vediyati.
an11.2:5.3.eng: It’s only natural to feel bliss when your body is tranquil.

an11.2:6.1.eng: When you feel bliss you need not make a wish:

an11.2:6.2.eng: ‘May my mind be immersed in samādhi!’

an11.2:6.3.pli: Dhammatā esā, bhikkhave, yaṃ sukhino cittaṃ samādhiyati.
an11.2:6.3.eng: It’s only natural for the mind to become immersed in samādhi when you feel bliss.

an11.2:7.1.eng: When your mind is immersed in samādhi you need not make a wish:

an11.2:7.3.pli: Dhammatā esā, bhikkhave, yaṃ samāhito yathābhūtaṃ jānāti passati.
an11.2:7.3.eng: It’s only natural to truly know and see when your mind is immersed in samādhi.

an11.2:8.1.pli: Yathābhūtaṃ, bhikkhave, jānato passato na cetanāya karaṇīyaṃ:
an11.2:8.1.eng: When you truly know and see you need not make a wish:

an11.2:8.3.pli: Dhammatā esā, bhikkhave, yaṃ yathābhūtaṃ jānaṃ passaṃ nibbindati.
an11.2:8.3.eng: It’s only natural to grow disillusioned when you truly know and see.

an11.2:9.1.eng: When you’re disillusioned you need not make a wish:

an11.2:9.3.pli: Dhammatā esā, bhikkhave, yaṃ nibbinno virajjati.
an11.2:9.3.eng: It’s only natural to grow dispassionate when you’re disillusioned.

an11.2:10.1.eng: When you’re dispassionate you need not make a wish:

an11.2:10.2.eng: ‘May I realize the knowledge and vision of freedom!’

an11.2:10.3.pli: Dhammatā esā, bhikkhave, yaṃ viratto vimuttiñāṇadassanaṃ sacchikaroti.
an11.2:10.3.eng: It’s only natural to realize the knowledge and vision of freedom when you’re dispassionate.

an11.2:11.1.pli: Iti kho, bhikkhave, virāgo vimuttiñāṇadassanattho vimuttiñāṇadassanānisaṃso, nibbidā virāgatthā virāgānisaṃsā, yathābhūtañāṇadassanaṃ nibbidatthaṃ nibbidānisaṃsaṃ, samādhi yathābhūtañāṇadassanattho yathābhūtañāṇadassanānisaṃso, sukhaṃ samādhatthaṃ samādhānisaṃsaṃ, passaddhi sukhatthā sukhānisaṃsā, pīti passaddhatthā passaddhānisaṃsā, pāmojjaṃ pītatthaṃ pītānisaṃsaṃ, avippaṭisāro pāmojjattho pāmojjānisaṃso, kusalāni sīlāni avippaṭisāratthāni avippaṭisārānisaṃsāni.
an11.2:11.1.eng: And so, mendicants, the knowledge and vision of freedom is the purpose and benefit of dispassion. Dispassion is the purpose and benefit of disillusionment. Disillusionment is the purpose and benefit of truly knowing and seeing. Truly knowing and seeing is the purpose and benefit of immersion. Immersion is the purpose and benefit of bliss. Bliss is the purpose and benefit of tranquility. Tranquility is the purpose and benefit of rapture. Rapture is the purpose and benefit of joy. Joy is the purpose and benefit of not having regrets. Not having regrets is the purpose and benefit of skillful ethics.

an11.2:11.2.pli: Iti kho, bhikkhave, dhammā dhamme abhisandenti, dhammā dhamme paripūrenti apārā pāraṃ gamanāyā”ti.
an11.2:11.2.eng: And so, mendicants, good qualities flow on and fill up from one to the other, for going from the near shore to the far shore.”

an11.20:1.1.pli: Atha kho sambahulā bhikkhū yenāyasmā sāriputto tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā sāriputtena saddhiṃ sammodiṃsu.
an11.20:1.1.eng: And then several mendicants went up to Venerable Sāriputta, and exchanged greetings with him.

an11.20:1.2.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho te bhikkhū āyasmantaṃ sāriputtaṃ etadavocuṃ:
an11.20:1.2.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, they sat down to one side and said to him:

an11.20:2.1.pli: “Siyā nu kho, āvuso sāriputta, bhikkhuno tathārūpo samādhipaṭilābho yathā neva pathaviyaṃ pathavisaññī assa …pe… yampidaṃ diṭṭhaṃ sutaṃ mutaṃ viññātaṃ pattaṃ pariyesitaṃ anuvicaritaṃ manasā tatrāpi na saññī assa; saññī ca pana assā”ti?
an11.20:2.1.eng: “Could it be, reverend, that a mendicant might gain a state of immersion like this? They wouldn’t perceive earth in earth, water in water, fire in fire, or air in air. And they wouldn’t perceive the dimension of infinite space in the dimension of infinite space, the dimension of infinite consciousness in the dimension of infinite consciousness, the dimension of nothingness in the dimension of nothingness, or the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception. They wouldn’t perceive this world in this world, or the other world in the other world. And they wouldn’t perceive what is seen, heard, thought, known, attained, sought, or explored by the mind. And yet they would still perceive.”

an11.20:2.2.pli: “Siyā, āvuso, bhikkhuno tathārūpo samādhipaṭilābho yathā neva pathaviyaṃ pathavisaññī assa …pe… yampidaṃ diṭṭhaṃ sutaṃ mutaṃ viññātaṃ pattaṃ pariyesitaṃ anuvicaritaṃ manasā tatrāpi na saññī assa; saññī ca pana assā”ti.

an11.20:3.1.pli: “Yathā kathaṃ pana, āvuso sāriputta, siyā bhikkhuno tathārūpo samādhipaṭilābho yathā neva pathaviyaṃ pathavisaññī assa …pe… yampidaṃ diṭṭhaṃ sutaṃ mutaṃ viññātaṃ pattaṃ pariyesitaṃ anuvicaritaṃ manasā tatrāpi na saññī assa; saññī ca pana assā”ti?

an11.20:4.2.pli: ‘etaṃ santaṃ etaṃ paṇītaṃ, yadidaṃ sabbasaṅkhārasamatho sabbūpadhipaṭinissaggo taṇhākkhayo virāgo nirodho nibbānan’ti.
an11.20:4.2.eng: ‘This is peaceful; this is sublime—that is, the stilling of all activities, the letting go of all attachments, the ending of craving, fading away, cessation, extinguishment.’

an11.20:4.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, āvuso, siyā bhikkhuno tathārūpo samādhipaṭilābho yathā neva pathaviyaṃ pathavisaññī assa …pe… yampidaṃ diṭṭhaṃ sutaṃ mutaṃ viññātaṃ pattaṃ pariyesitaṃ anuvicaritaṃ manasā tatrāpi na saññī assa; saññī ca pana assā”ti.
an11.20:4.3.eng: That’s how a mendicant might gain a state of immersion like this. They wouldn’t perceive earth in earth, water in water, fire in fire, or air in air. And they wouldn’t perceive the dimension of infinite space in the dimension of infinite space, the dimension of infinite consciousness in the dimension of infinite consciousness, the dimension of nothingness in the dimension of nothingness, or the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception. They wouldn’t perceive this world in this world, or the other world in the other world. And they wouldn’t perceive what is seen, heard, thought, known, attained, sought, or explored by the mind. And yet they would still perceive.”

an11.21:1.1.pli: Tatra kho āyasmā sāriputto bhikkhū āmantesi:

an11.21:1.2.pli: “siyā nu kho, āvuso, bhikkhuno tathārūpo samādhipaṭilābho yathā neva pathaviyaṃ pathavisaññī assa, na āpasmiṃ āposaññī assa, na tejasmiṃ tejosaññī assa, na vāyasmiṃ vāyosaññī assa, na ākāsānañcāyatane ākāsānañcāyatanasaññī assa, na viññāṇañcāyatane viññāṇañcāyatanasaññī assa, na ākiñcaññāyatane ākiñcaññāyatanasaññī assa, na nevasaññānāsaññāyatane nevasaññānāsaññāyatanasaññī assa, na idhaloke idhalokasaññī assa, na paraloke paralokasaññī assa, yampidaṃ diṭṭhaṃ sutaṃ mutaṃ viññātaṃ pattaṃ pariyesitaṃ anuvicaritaṃ manasā tatrāpi na saññī assa; saññī ca pana assā”ti?
an11.21:1.2.eng: “Could it be, reverends, that a mendicant might gain a state of immersion like this? They wouldn’t perceive earth in earth, water in water, fire in fire, or air in air. And they wouldn’t perceive the dimension of infinite space in the dimension of infinite space, the dimension of infinite consciousness in the dimension of infinite consciousness, the dimension of nothingness in the dimension of nothingness, or the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception. They wouldn’t perceive this world in this world, or the other world in the other world. And they wouldn’t perceive what is seen, heard, thought, known, attained, sought, or explored by the mind. And yet they would still perceive.”

an11.21:2.1.pli: “Dūratopi kho mayaṃ, āvuso, āgaccheyyāma āyasmato sāriputtassa santike etassa bhāsitassa atthamaññātuṃ.
an11.21:2.1.eng: “Reverend, we would travel a long way to learn the meaning of this statement in the presence of Venerable Sāriputta.

an11.21:2.2.pli: Sādhu vatāyasmantaṃyeva sāriputtaṃ paṭibhātu etassa bhāsitassa attho.
an11.21:2.2.eng: May Venerable Sāriputta himself please clarify the meaning of this.

an11.21:2.3.eng: The mendicants will listen and remember it.”

an11.21:3.1.eng: “Then listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

an11.21:3.2.pli: “Evamāvuso”ti kho te bhikkhū āyasmato sāriputtassa paccassosuṃ.

an11.21:4.1.pli: “Siyā, āvuso, bhikkhuno tathārūpo samādhipaṭilābho yathā neva pathaviyaṃ pathavisaññī assa …pe… yampidaṃ diṭṭhaṃ sutaṃ mutaṃ viññātaṃ pattaṃ pariyesitaṃ anuvicaritaṃ manasā tatrāpi na saññī assa; saññī ca pana assā”ti.
an11.21:4.1.eng: “A mendicant could gain such a state of immersion.”

an11.21:5.1.pli: “Yathā kathaṃ panāvuso, siyā bhikkhuno tathārūpo samādhipaṭilābho yathā neva pathaviyaṃ pathavisaññī assa …pe… yampidaṃ diṭṭhaṃ sutaṃ mutaṃ viññātaṃ pattaṃ pariyesitaṃ anuvicaritaṃ manasā tatrāpi na saññī assa; saññī ca pana assā”ti?

an11.21:6.2.pli: ‘etaṃ santaṃ etaṃ paṇītaṃ, yadidaṃ sabbasaṅkhārasamatho sabbūpadhipaṭinissaggo taṇhākkhayo virāgo nirodho nibbānan’ti.
an11.21:6.2.eng: ‘This is peaceful; this is sublime—that is, the stilling of all activities, the letting go of all attachments, the ending of craving, fading away, cessation, extinguishment.’

an11.21:6.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, āvuso, siyā bhikkhuno tathārūpo samādhipaṭilābho yathā neva pathaviyaṃ pathavisaññī assa, na āpasmiṃ āposaññī assa, na tejasmiṃ tejosaññī assa, na vāyasmiṃ vāyosaññī assa, na ākāsānañcāyatane ākāsānañcāyatanasaññī assa, na viññāṇañcāyatane viññāṇañcāyatanasaññī assa, na ākiñcaññāyatane ākiñcaññāyatanasaññī assa, na nevasaññānāsaññāyatane nevasaññānāsaññāyatanasaññī assa, na idhaloke idhalokasaññī assa, na paraloke paralokasaññī assa, yampidaṃ diṭṭhaṃ sutaṃ mutaṃ viññātaṃ pattaṃ pariyesitaṃ anuvicaritaṃ manasā tatrāpi na saññī assa; saññī ca pana assā”ti.
an11.21:6.3.eng: That’s how a mendicant might gain a state of immersion like this. They wouldn’t perceive earth in earth, water in water, fire in fire, or air in air. And they wouldn’t perceive the dimension of infinite space in the dimension of infinite space, the dimension of infinite consciousness in the dimension of infinite consciousness, the dimension of nothingness in the dimension of nothingness, or the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception. They wouldn’t perceive this world in this world, or the other world in the other world. And they wouldn’t perceive what is seen, heard, thought, known, attained, sought, or explored by the mind. And yet they would still perceive.”

an11.214-261:0.4.eng: Untitled Discourses on Feeling Born of Eye Contact, Etc.

an11.22:1.1.pli: “Ekādasahi, bhikkhave, aṅgehi samannāgato gopālako abhabbo gogaṇaṃ pariharituṃ phātiṃ kātuṃ.
an11.22:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a cowherd with eleven factors can’t maintain and expand a herd of cattle.

an11.22:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, gopālako na rūpaññū hoti, na lakkhaṇakusalo hoti, na āsāṭikaṃ hāretā hoti, na vaṇaṃ paṭicchādetā hoti, na dhūmaṃ kattā hoti, na titthaṃ jānāti, na pītaṃ jānāti, na vīthiṃ jānāti, na gocarakusalo hoti, anavasesadohī ca hoti, ye te usabhā gopitaro gopariṇāyakā te na atirekapūjāya pūjetā hoti—
an11.22:1.3.eng: It’s when a cowherd doesn’t know form, is unskilled in characteristics, doesn’t pick out flies’ eggs, doesn’t dress wounds, doesn’t spread smoke, doesn’t know the ford, doesn’t know satisfaction, doesn’t know the trail, is not skilled in pastures, milks dry, and doesn’t show extra respect to the bulls who are fathers and captains of the herd.

an11.22:1.4.pli: imehi kho, bhikkhave, ekādasahi aṅgehi samannāgato gopālako abhabbo gogaṇaṃ pariharituṃ phātiṃ kātuṃ.
an11.22:1.4.eng: A cowherd with these eleven factors can’t maintain and expand a herd of cattle.

an11.22:2.1.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, ekādasahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu abhabbo cakkhusmiṃ aniccānupassī viharituṃ…
an11.22:2.1.eng: In the same way, a mendicant with eleven qualities can’t meditate observing impermanence in the eye …

an11.262-309:0.4.eng: Untitled Discourses on Perception of Sights, Etc.

an11.3:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, an unethical person, who lacks ethics, has destroyed a vital condition for having no regrets.

an11.3:1.2.pli: Avippaṭisāre asati avippaṭisāravipannassa hatūpanisaṃ hoti pāmojjaṃ.
an11.3:1.2.eng: When there are regrets, one who has regrets has destroyed a vital condition for joy.

an11.3:1.3.pli: Pāmojje asati pāmojjavipannassa hatūpanisā hoti pīti.
an11.3:1.3.eng: When there is no joy, one who lacks joy has destroyed a vital condition for rapture.

an11.3:1.4.pli: Pītiyā asati pītivipannassa hatūpanisā hoti passaddhi.
an11.3:1.4.eng: When there is no rapture, one who lacks rapture has destroyed a vital condition for tranquility.

an11.3:1.5.pli: Passaddhiyā asati passaddhivipannassa hatūpanisaṃ hoti sukhaṃ.
an11.3:1.5.eng: When there is no tranquility, one who lacks tranquility has destroyed a vital condition for bliss.

an11.3:1.6.pli: Sukhe asati sukhavipannassa hatūpaniso hoti sammāsamādhi.
an11.3:1.6.eng: When there is no bliss, one who lacks bliss has destroyed a vital condition for right immersion.

an11.3:1.7.pli: Sammāsamādhimhi asati sammāsamādhivipannassa hatūpanisaṃ hoti yathābhūtañāṇadassanaṃ.
an11.3:1.7.eng: When there is no right immersion, one who lacks right immersion has destroyed a vital condition for true knowledge and vision.

an11.3:1.8.pli: Yathābhūtañāṇadassane asati yathābhūtañāṇadassanavipannassa hatūpanisā hoti nibbidā.
an11.3:1.8.eng: When there is no true knowledge and vision, one who lacks true knowledge and vision has destroyed a vital condition for disillusionment.

an11.3:1.9.pli: Nibbidāya asati nibbidāvipannassa hatūpaniso hoti virāgo.
an11.3:1.9.eng: When there is no disillusionment, one who lacks disillusionment has destroyed a vital condition for dispassion.

an11.3:1.10.pli: Virāge asati virāgavipannassa hatūpanisaṃ hoti vimuttiñāṇadassanaṃ.
an11.3:1.10.eng: When there is no dispassion, one who lacks dispassion has destroyed a vital condition for knowledge and vision of freedom.

an11.3:2.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, rukkho sākhāpalāsavipanno. Tassa papaṭikāpi na pāripūriṃ gacchati, tacopi … pheggupi … sāropi na pāripūriṃ gacchati.
an11.3:2.1.eng: Suppose there was a tree that lacked branches and foliage. Its shoots, bark, softwood, and heartwood would not grow to fullness.

an11.3:2.2.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, dussīlassa sīlavipannassa hatūpaniso hoti avippaṭisāro,
an11.3:2.2.eng: In the same way, an unethical person, who lacks ethics, has destroyed a vital condition for having no regrets.

an11.3:2.3.pli: avippaṭisāre asati avippaṭisāravipannassa hatūpanisaṃ hoti pāmojjaṃ …pe…
an11.3:2.3.eng: When there are regrets, one who has regrets has destroyed a vital condition for joy. …

an11.3:2.4.eng: When there is no dispassion, one who lacks dispassion has destroyed a vital condition for knowledge and vision of freedom.

an11.3:3.1.pli: Sīlavato, bhikkhave, sīlasampannassa upanisasampanno hoti avippaṭisāro,
an11.3:3.1.eng: An ethical person, who has fulfilled ethics, has fulfilled a vital condition for not having regrets.

an11.3:3.2.pli: avippaṭisāre sati avippaṭisārasampannassa upanisasampannaṃ hoti pāmojjaṃ,
an11.3:3.2.eng: When there are no regrets, one who has no regrets has fulfilled a vital condition for joy.

an11.3:3.3.pli: pāmojje sati pāmojjasampannassa upanisasampannā hoti pīti,
an11.3:3.3.eng: When there is joy, one who has fulfilled joy has fulfilled a vital condition for rapture.

an11.3:3.4.pli: pītiyā sati pītisampannassa upanisasampannā hoti passaddhi,
an11.3:3.4.eng: When there is rapture, one who has fulfilled rapture has fulfilled a vital condition for tranquility.

an11.3:3.5.pli: passaddhiyā sati passaddhisampannassa upanisasampannaṃ hoti sukhaṃ,
an11.3:3.5.eng: When there is tranquility, one who has fulfilled tranquility has fulfilled a vital condition for bliss.

an11.3:3.6.pli: sukhe sati sukhasampannassa upanisasampanno hoti sammāsamādhi,
an11.3:3.6.eng: When there is bliss, one who has fulfilled bliss has fulfilled a vital condition for right immersion.

an11.3:3.7.pli: sammāsamādhimhi sati sammāsamādhisampannassa upanisasampannaṃ hoti yathābhūtañāṇadassanaṃ,
an11.3:3.7.eng: When there is right immersion, one who has fulfilled right immersion has fulfilled a vital condition for true knowledge and vision.

an11.3:3.8.pli: yathābhūtañāṇadassane sati yathābhūtañāṇadassanasampannassa upanisasampannā hoti nibbidā,
an11.3:3.8.eng: When there is true knowledge and vision, one who has fulfilled true knowledge and vision has fulfilled a vital condition for disillusionment.

an11.3:3.9.pli: nibbidāya sati nibbidāsampannassa upanisasampanno hoti virāgo,
an11.3:3.9.eng: When there is disillusionment, one who has fulfilled disillusionment has fulfilled a vital condition for dispassion.

an11.3:3.10.pli: virāge sati virāgasampannassa upanisasampannaṃ hoti vimuttiñāṇadassanaṃ.
an11.3:3.10.eng: When there is dispassion, one who has fulfilled dispassion has fulfilled a vital condition for knowledge and vision of freedom.

an11.3:4.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, rukkho sākhāpalāsasampanno. Tassa papaṭikāpi pāripūriṃ gacchati, tacopi … pheggupi … sāropi pāripūriṃ gacchati.
an11.3:4.1.eng: Suppose there was a tree that was complete with branches and foliage. Its shoots, bark, softwood, and heartwood would grow to fullness.

an11.3:4.2.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, sīlavato sīlasampannassa upanisasampanno hoti avippaṭisāro,
an11.3:4.2.eng: In the same way, an ethical person, who has fulfilled ethics, has fulfilled a vital condition for not having regrets.

an11.3:4.3.eng: When there are no regrets, one who has no regrets has fulfilled a vital condition for joy. …

an11.3:4.4.eng: When there is dispassion, one who has fulfilled dispassion has fulfilled a vital condition for knowledge and vision of freedom.”

an11.30-69:0.4.eng: Untitled Discourses on the Ear, Etc.

an11.310-357:0.4.eng: Untitled Discourses on Intention Regarding Sights, Etc.

an11.358-405:0.4.eng: Untitled Discourses on Craving For Sights, Etc.
